newsitem.title: USA: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS --up 1/2 after inflation data.
newsitem.headline: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS --up 1/2 after inflation data.

text.p: U.S. municipal bond prices gained at least 1/2 point Wednesday mainly on the strength of a favorable inflation report, market participants said.
"It was pretty active, there was a lot of secondary trading," one trader said.
Treasury prices outpaced the gains in muncipals, after the Labor Department said consumer prices in June rose just 0.1 percent overall, versus expectations for a 0.2 percent rise.
The figure was another piece of reassuring news for investors counting on inflation to remain tame, and offered more validation for the Federal Reserve's decision to hold interest rates steady.
The government long bond rallied throughout the day, breaking through the 6.50 percent yield barrier late in the session on price gains of nearly a full point.
In new issue news, Merrill Lynch & Co. said it postponed until next week a $162 million Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corp refunding deal expected today.
Goldman Sachs & Co said it repriced United Nations Development Corp's $162 million issue, lowering yields. .
Bear Stearns & Co. said it repriced $38 million Methodist Health Systems, Tenn., bonds, cutting yields and lowering the par amount from $47 million.

On the competitive side, Raymond James & Associates won the largest deal, a $41 million Texas Public Facilities Authority deal, and reoffered the 2015 maturity at 5.25 percent. The 2017 was not formally reoffered.
September municipal bond futures closed up 29/32 to 120-13/32, while September Treasury bond futures gained 24/32 to 114-22/32. The MOB spread widened to 183 ticks from 178 at the close on Tuesday.
In the secondary market, bids on Bexar County, Texas, MBIA 5-1/4s of 2027 were down one basis point to 5.52 percent.
Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority FGIC 5.0s of 2027 were down four basis points to 5.35 percent.
Municipal bond sales for Thursday were expected to total $422 million in 22 sales, according to Reuters Municipal Bond Information Group.
Negotiated offerings total $133 million in eight sales, with a $32 million Colorado Regional Transportation District offering through George K. Baum & Co. topping the list.
On the competitive side, 14 sales totaling $290 million are scheduled. A $200 million Florida Department of Transportation offering at 1100 EDT is the largest.
